其它说明

微分几何

课程编码：011M1004H 英文名称：Differential Geometry 课时：60 学分：4.00 课程属性：一级学科核心课 主讲教师：段海豹等

教学目的要求
本课程为数学学科基础数学专业几何拓扑方向博士、硕士研究生的核心课程，同时也可作为应用数学、理论物理等相关专业研究生的选修课。近代微分几何的范围很广，本课程主要介绍黎曼流形及子流形的几何。
通过本课程的学习，希望学生能掌握近代微分几何的基本概念和基本技巧，对微分几何的近代发展有所了解，为进一步学习现代数学和从事专业研究打下基础。

预修课程
高等数学、线性代数、曲线和曲面论、点集拓扑、微分流形。

教材

主要内容
第一章 联络和曲率
（1）仿射联络；R^n及子流形上的联络；流形上的仿射联络；挠率和曲率。
（2）黎曼度量； 黎曼联络；黎曼几何基本定理；共变微分。
（3）黎曼曲率；常曲率空间；共形变换。
（4）Hodge星算子； Laplace-Beltrami算子；Hodge定理及其几何应用。
第二章 测地线及其应用
（1）测地线；指数映射；法坐标；测地完备性。
（2）弧长的第一、第二变分公式；Jacobi场；共轭点。
第三章 黎曼子流形
（1）等距浸入，基本方程，活动标架，常曲率空间的子流形。
（2）超曲面的基本公式及其应用，主曲率，欧氏空间的超曲面。
（3）体积的变分，欧氏空间的极小子流形，球面上的极小子流形，Simons不等式。

参考文献
1. 白正国，沈一兵等，《黎曼几何初步（修订版）》，高等教育出版社，北京，2004.
2. S. Kobayashi and K. Nomizu, Foudations of differential geometry, VOL I, II, Interscience publishers, 1969.
3. 陈省身、陈维桓著，《微分几何讲义》，北京大学出版社，北京，1983。

课程编码：162MX004Z 英文名称：Magnetic Resonance Imaging 课时：40 学分：2.00 课程属性：一级学科核心课 主讲教师：薛蓉等

教学目的要求
Basic MRI covers the basic principles of magnetic resonance (MR) imaging and its use in research. This includes spin dynamics in a magnetic field, interaction of magnetization by radiofrequency pulses, principles of MR imaging using magnetic field gradients, relaxation of magnetization and contrast in images. The most important applications of MR will be introduced. These include angiography and blood flow measurement, perfusion and diffusion assessment and functional MRI. Besides, examples of the clinical use of MR imaging will be given.

预修课程

教材
Book: Introduction to medical imaging: Physics, Engineering and Clinical Applications by Nadine Narrie Smith and Andrew Webb, Cambridge University Press (2011)
- ISBN 978-0-521-19065-7
Lectures notes and PowerPoint presentations
Westbrook et al: MRI in practice, Wiley-Blackwell 2011. A few chapters from this book will be handed out.
Articles: Roberts T et al.; Neuro MR; Principles; Magn. Reson. Imaging 2007; 26; 823-837

主要内容
Knowledge
Basic principles of
- Magnetic dipole moments in a magnetic field
- Image formation
- Obtaining contrast in MR images
- Using MRI for various physiological measurements
- Clinical MRI
Skills
- Possess overall knowledge of fundamental MRI and the clinical use of MRI
- Understand which kind of research problems MR can be used for
- Understand the limitations of MR
Competencies
- Participate in research projects using MRI
- Participate in evaluation of MR scanners for equipment purchasing

课程名称: 神经科学模式识别和预测建模
英文名称: Pattern Recognition and Predictive Modelling in Neuroscience
详细内容:
神经科学模式识别和预测建模

课程编码：162MX005Z 英文名称：Pattern Recognition and Predictive Modelling in Neuroscience 课时：40 学分：2.00 课程属性：一级学科核心课 主讲教师：张三国

教学目的要求
The aim of this course is to introduce pattern recognition and predictive modelling techniques and enable students to statistically analyze complex data sets as typically encountered in neuroscience. The course introduces topics in unsupervised and supervised learning beginning with presentations of unsupervised learning techniques such as k-means cluster analysis mixture models, as well as dimension reduction techniques. Within supervised learning, In addition, PRPM covers basic and advanced regression models for continuous and binary outcomes including penalized regression and support vector machines. The course emphasizes techniques for model training and assessment as well as variable selection.

预修课程
Knowledge and competence within mathematics equivalent to the Mathematics course in the master’s program. Basic knowledge in biostatistics (ANOVA, regression)

教材
Book: Pattern recognition and machine learning 2nd printing edition by Christopher M. Bishop (2007), Springer
• ISBN 978-0-387-31073-2
• Internet: http://www.amazon.cn/Pattern-Recognition-and-Machine-Learning-Bishop-Christopher-M/dp/0387310738
Book: Introduction to Statistical Learning.
• Internet: Available for free on pdf from this link http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~gareth/ISL

主要内容
Knowledge
At the end of the course the student will be able to:
- Understand mathematical and statistical principles in cluster analysis, Mixture models, Expectation maximization, Latent variable models, Dimension reduction, Regularized regression, Support Vector Machines, Classification, and Model assessment and selection
- Critically reflect on theoretical and practical strengths and shortcomings of the approaches

Skills
At the end of the course the student will be able to
- Apply unsupervised and supervised learning techniques particularly within neuroscience research
- Identify relevant techniques to solve particular problems, and discuss strengths and weaknesses of different approaches
- Concisely account for solution strategy and analysis results, as necessary for publication in scientific journals or prototyping machine learning algorithms

Competencies
At the end of the course the student will be able to
- Independently develop analysis strategies and apply combinations of statistical methodologies to solve research-based problems within neuroscience
- Become proficient in novel techniques (not covered in lectures) by studying and critically reviewing research articles

详细内容:
社会政策比较：理论与实际中的福利状况

课程编码：164MX005Z 英文名称：Comparing Social Policies: Welfare States in Theoryt and Practice 课时：120 学分：6.00 课程属性：一级学科核心课 主讲教师：张林秀

教学目的要求
In the end of the course, the students should be able to:
• Undertake an in-depth comparative analysis on a selected topic within social policy
• Conceptualize and analyze the effects of different welfare state arrangements on social equality, economic efficiency and political stability
• Conceptualize and analyze challenges to the welfare state emanating from social risks and different forms of social change in different settings
• Identify, discuss and evaluate solutions suggested to the kind of welfare challenges covered in the course

预修课程

教材

主要内容
The aim of this course is to provide empirical and theoretical insights into how different states and societies solve welfare questions. Using this foundation, the course engages topical discussions on challenges to welfare states across different social systems and welfare regimes. By doing so, students will not only be exposed to theories about welfare states and empirical material about different welfare regimes, but also be introduced to different tools of policy analysis.

社会创新

课程编码：164MX006Z 英文名称：Social Innovation 课时：60 学分：3.00 课程属性：一级学科核心课 主讲教师：-

教学目的要求
In the end of the course, the students should be able to:
• Discuss the differences between different theories of social innovation
• Explain how these theories link to social performance
• Define which variables impact the social performance of social enterprises
• Apply the theories to the analysis of social entrepreneurship in a wide range of cases
• Apply class room learning to a specific real-world example for which a business plan has to be prepared and defended

预修课程

教材

主要内容
This class is aimed to help SDC students to understand the processes underlying social innovation in areas such as for example the voluntary sector, microfinance, or fair trade. As a participant in this course you will be introduced to the theories around the topic of social innovation. You will also gain hands-on experience with the practice of business plan writing, applying the theoretical knowledge acquired. You are expected to identify a real-world opportunity in the form of an innovation that will create charitable or societal benefits, either being developed in the public or private sector. You will then be required to ”transfer” that idea into the real world. This will consist of developing a mission statement in which the intended social impact is identified clearly. Furthermore, you will have to identify and describe a business model, determining relevant market segments, income strategies, and financing models. This content will then be assimilated into a specific business plan. The course will be completed with the students presenting their business plans/opportunities.

教学目的要求
In the end of the course, the student should be able to:
• Appropriate and present knowledge through individual study of relevant scholarly literature and other relevant sources of data

• Report the outcome of his/her analysis in a clear and concise prose
• Carry out an analysis of the research problem based on either theoretical reasoning grounded in existing literature or empirical data analysis or a combination thereof

The individually studied subject serves as the first element in the student’s specialization. The purpose of the course is that the student gets an opportunity to investigate a particular topic that has his/her particular interest more in-depth, either on his/her own or in smaller, self-organised groups.

课程名称: 穿越形式：有关视觉艺术的五个专题
英文名称: The Visual Bible- Christianity in Western Art
详细内容:
穿越形式：有关视觉艺术的五个专题

课程编码：14MGX204H 英文名称：The Visual Bible- Christianity in Western Art 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：张浩达

教学目的要求
艺术与我们人类的关系是如此的密切，以至于我们在谈到文化现象的时候常常首先浮现在脑海中的实例基本上都是关乎艺术的。
今天，媒介已经变身成了内容的一部分。数字的移动记录设备与移动播放器使得我们每个人既是信息的接受者，又是信息的制作者和传播者。对数字媒体而言，最重要的功能就是互动。
让学生们站在科学的角度看待视觉艺术。视觉艺术反映了人类视觉认知的历史以及人类用自我创造的视觉形态与符号对人类视觉认知过程的描述。艺术家带给大众的不仅仅是图像，而且还给大众提供了一个透过其艺术作品以一种全新的态度来审视人生、社会和审视人类对主观世界和客观世界认知的价值定义和思考。透过图像，我们可以感受到艺术家超越时空的人文情怀和作品带给我们的永恒与美好，正是这些永恒的美好，使其在历史的长河中不断焕发出生生不息的力量。

预修课程

教材

主要内容
专题1、视觉艺术活动与公共艺术（4学时）
专题2、视觉艺术中的活动影像（4学时）
专题3、视觉艺术中的多媒体视频（4学时）
专题4、视觉艺术中的动画形态（4学时）
专题5、学习用手机拍摄与编辑视觉作品（4学时）
教学方式：

课程名称: 科学技术之于环境：欠缺及其出路
英文名称: Science and Technology to Environment: Scarcity and Way Out
详细内容:
科学技术之于环境：欠缺及其出路

课程编码：14MGX203H 英文名称：Science and Technology to Environment: Scarcity and Way Out 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：肖显静

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容

本课程为理工科研究生，尤其是与环境问题相关专业的研究生的选修课。
本课程的主要内容是在相关科学哲学、技术哲学、科学技术论等关于科学、技术论述的基础上，结合具体的科学、技术与环境案例，分析科学、技术之所以造成环境问题的根本原因，探讨有利于环境保护的科学发展方向以及技术创新之路，展现科学技术的新发展与新产生的环境风险之间的关联，明确科学技术在解决环境问题中的地位和限度。
通过本课程的学习，要求学生在深刻理解科学、技术的基础上，能够从本体论、认识论、方法论、价值论的角度，弄清科学、技术造成环境问题的原因，明确有利于环境保护的科学技术发展方向，理解科学技术在解决环境问题中的限度，全方位地了解科学技术与环境问题的产生及解决之间的关联，并将此指导今后的科学技术研究及其应用实践，为有利于环境保护的科学技术创新服务。

内容提要
第一讲 科学技术之于环境：天使抑或魔鬼
好的归科学，坏的归人类吗？好的归科学，坏的归技术吗？天使抑或魔鬼，这是个问题。
第二讲 科学造成环境问题的原因分析
科学之生与自然之死；科学之得与自然之失；科学之建构与自然之破坏。
第三讲 进行新的科学革命以利于环境保护
走向自然的返魅之路；掀开自然的复杂性面纱；回归自然的怀抱；探讨人与自然的关系。
第四讲 技术的本质缺陷与环境技术创新
技术的本质与环境问题的产生；从技术创新到环境技术创新；环境技术创新的新形态。
第五讲 科学技术解决环境问题的限度
科技应用会产生新的环境问题；科学认识环境问题的局限；科技解决环境问题的艰难；仅有科技还是不够的。
第六讲 走向可持续发展的社会
国内政治和国际政治的困境；环境保护中的市场失灵与激励；消费主义文化的环境之痛；从“人类中心主义”走向“非人类中心主义”。
第七讲 案例分析：转基因技术风险及其解决
转基因技术的本质特征；转基因技术风险的产生；转基因技术风险的解决：从常规科学走向后常规科学。

主要参考书
1、肖显静：《环境•科学——非自然、反自然与回归自然》，化学工业出版社，2009年版。2、卢风：《人、环境与自然——环境哲学导论》，广东人民出版社，2011年版。
3、杨志峰、刘静玲：《环境科学概论》，高等教育出版社，2004年版。

撰写人：肖显静

诗词鉴赏

课程编码：14MGX205H 英文名称：Poetry Appreciation 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：刘京臣

教学目的要求
一、通过诗歌参证历史或通过历史印证诗歌，寻找诗中的文化、文化中的诗。文学不仅在短短的方寸之间为我们展示了过去的琼楼玉宇，逼真地复制了那在过去岁月中也许早已为人们淡忘了的生动具体的细节，而且还为我们塑造了一个活生生的人群，一种生活的韵味，一片奇妙的风光。不习之，何以知之？
　　　二、诗歌能培养诗人的才情、哲人的思辩、历史学家的深沉。经典诗词可以使现代人在物欲横流而灵魂放逐的年代有一块属于自己的精神家园，并可以在其中诗意栖居。
　　　三、“一代有一代之文学”，从上古的神话到明清小说，每一个朝代都有其独领风骚的文学作品和文学现象，方今盛世，我们正应当将这些宝贵精神财富继承与传承下去。

当代美国史

课程编码：14MGX206H 英文名称：US History since 1945 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：王作跃

教学目的要求
这门课主要介绍美国第二次世界大战以后的社会政治、外交关系的演化，重点有两个：一个是冷战，另一个是民权运动，二者塑造、改变了美国社会，而且二者之间有极大的关联。这门课从杜鲁门到奥巴马，研究内容包括原子弹的制造和使用、冷战的开启、朝鲜战争、麦卡锡主义、苏联卫星升天的冲击、民权运动、越南战争、妇女运动、环保运动、冷战结束、计算机网络和生物新技术兴起、9/11恐怖袭击及其后果、气候变化、奥巴马的当选、经济大衰退的影响等。我们关注的问题包括：国际政治和国内政治如何互相影响？技术是美国当代史的主要驱动力吗？美国从1945 到2014年有那些变化、又有哪些没有变化？我们的主要学习方式为课下阅读和写作、课上讲演、讨论、视频，以求获得没够近代史的知识，并改进批判性思维、写作和口头交流的能力。

临床心理学

课程编码：14MGX208H 英文名称：Clinical Psychology 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：高文斌

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
本课程为心理学学科各专业博士、硕士研究生的学科专业基础课。
临床心理学(Clinical Psychology)是运用心理学的知识和原理，帮助病人纠正自己的精神和行为障碍，通过心理学的技术指导和培养健全的人，以便有效地适应环境和更有创造力。临床心理学属于应用心理学的范畴，各种心理问题和心理障碍的人是临床心理学的主要研究对象，但正常的心理过程也是临床心理学研究的范围。
从临床心理学的基本工作性质来看，它确实是以帮助有行为障碍和精神疾病的人尽快康复为目的，而临床心理学是运用心理学知识帮助病人康复的应用学科。然而，临床心理学的任务并非仅限于此，它的工作范围还包括正常人，用心理学知识和技能缓解人们的心理压力，解决人们的心理问题，培养和训练人们良好的个性，使其达到最有成效的水平幷具有良好的适应能力，使正常人的精神活动更具有创造力。临床心理学领域和课题、理论与方法、研究与应用等诸多方面已有极大地扩展，而且与心理学其他分支学科的交叉和融合也日益增多。
通过本课程的学习，希望学生掌握临床心理学的基本概念及技巧，对心理学的发展有所了解，为进一步从事专业研究打下基础。

中国科学院心理研究所心理所心理咨询与治疗中心主任，中科院心理健康重点实验室副研究员，中国科学院团委委员。
中国心理学会心理学普及工作委员会副主任、医学心理学专委会委员，中国心理卫生协会青少年心理卫生专业委员会委员，北京市心理卫生协会理事，北京市朝阳区青联委员。
从临床心理学研究与实践工作，积累了大量的临床心理治疗与咨询经验，先后担任心理所心理咨询社社长、中科院职工心理咨询中心主任等职，参加了关于选择性注意作用时程的事件相关电位研究、意识脑机制的视觉ERP--fMRI研究等国家、科学院重大项目。
在2003年“非典”肆虐期间，在国家卫生部、北京市政府和中国科学院共同支持下，主持了“非典患者与医护人员心理干预项目”，带领同事与研究生深入小汤山医院、中日友好医院等非典一线，开展了大量研究与临床工作，受到多级部门和领导嘉奖。
目前任中科院心理所心理咨询与治疗中心主任，主持“网络成瘾心理依赖脑机制的事件相关电位研究”、“网络成瘾心理治疗与预防”等国家、省部级项目，致力于心理健康的研究与推动工作。

教学目的要求
教学目的和要求: 　本课程为面向研究生的公共选修课，无专业限制。　通过本课程的学习，增进学生的心理健康知识，提高学生应用心理知识改善自身心理健康的能力。

预修课程

教材

主要内容
第1讲 导论：你的局限与自由
了解遗传对心理行为的影响；早期经验对心理行为的影响；心理特征的代际传递；导读《少有人走的路》。

男女婚恋中的男人与女人了解婚恋的不同阶段；两性在各阶段的不同需求；导读《坏女人有人爱》。

课程编码：15MGX020H 英文名称：World Englishes and Academic Writing 课时：18 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：徐志长

教学目的要求
本课程主要介绍世界英语这门学科的发展与现状，以及理论与实践。同时本课程也以世界英语为主要理论框架，探讨在英语为国际通用语言环境下的英语学术写作等问题。本课程的目的是使学生能够了解世界英语的基本理论和在学术写作中的应用。本课程的教学要求是，学生具有本科以上的英语基础，并了解一些各英语变体（例如英国英语，美国英语和中国英语）之间的差异和相似之处。同时，学生应该具有一定的英语写作基础和实践经验。

预修课程

教材
自定自编讲义

主要内容
本课程的主要内容包括：1）世界英语的起源和主要理论；2）“外圈”英语的发展现状；3）中国英语研究与实践；4）在不同文化下的学术写作研究；5）跨文化词义变化：世界英语使用者的文化交际研究；6）学术写作成功个案分析

参考文献
Kirkpatrick, Andy (2007) World Englishes: Implications for Intercultural Communication and English Language Teaching. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press
Xu, Zhichang (2010) Chinese English: Features and Implications. Hong Kong: Open University of Hong Kong Press
Xu, Zhichang, Wang, Lixun, Jenny Chan Wong, and DeCoursy, Matthew (2011) Academic Writing in Language and Education Programmes, Pearson Education, Singapore

徐志长博士，现任澳大利亚墨尔本墨纳士大学国际英语教研室主任，讲师。研究领域包括世界英语、中国英语、英语教学、跨文化交际、英语写作等。主要讲授的课程包括世界英语、语言与全球化、国际英语研究、跨文化写作、语言与跨文化交际。

教学目的要求
本课程主要介绍跨文化交际中的一些主要概念和理论。其中包括语境的重要性，跨文化礼貌问题，话语分析，名称与称谓的文化差异，跨文化网络交际与翻译实践，以及跨文化交际策略等。本课程的教学目的是使学生能够了解并掌握用英语进行跨文化交际过程中所常见的概念和理论，并能够把理论与实践相结合，用相关的理论来指导跨文化交际实践，或解释相关的跨文化交际现象。本课程的要求是，学生具有一定的英语使用和交际能力，并对跨文化交际的基本概念，比如礼貌问题，称谓问题，交际策略等有所了解。

美国民间音乐

课程编码：15MGX022H 英文名称：American Folk Music 课时：16 学分：0.50 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Randy Abel

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材
讲义（自编）

主要内容
For our purposes, American Folk Music (a.k.a. “roots music”) refers to the Country and Blues traditions which flourished in the early 20th century to lay the foundation for every uniquely-American musical style which followed. Highlighting nearly a century of recordings, our course will be a cultural journey facilitated by close examination of stories told and legends passed through selected songs (primary sources). To provide cultural context, we will also explore relevant secondary sources on the subject as we investigate the historical impact of the musical form which has shaped national’s character and celebrate the artistic legacy which American Folk Music has fostered world-wide.

By the end of our course, students will be able to:
 recognize and identify folk music styles and their regional/overseas influences.
 examine and interpret meanings of song lyrics and the historical events they chronicled and/or influenced.
 appreciate the ongoing effect American Folk Music has had on popular forms of music across the globe.

Attendance policy: Students are required to attend each lesson.

Homework policy:
Students will be responsible for researching and presenting on selected topics. My final assessment of the course grade will be based on the merits of each individual’s participation in a group presentation. The subject of this presentation will be a specialized era of American Folk Music and each group will develop their expertise in this area throughout the term.

Grading policy:
Determined on a 100-point scale based on the following criteria:
 Attendance: 25 points (five-point deletion for each excused leave; three-point deletion for each absence)
 Assignments and activities: 40 points
 Classroom Participation: 10 points
 Final Presentation: 25 points

Textbook: See proposed syllabus

1. Smith, Harry. Anthology of American Folk Music (Parts 1-3). Smithsonian Folkways Recordings. 1952, 1997.
2. Dunson, Josh and Ethel Raim (eds). Anthology of American Folk Music. New York: Oak Publications, 1973.
3. Various multimedia materials which I’ll provide throughout the term.

Main teaching methods: Lectures and class discussion.

Other important issues to know:
As stated above, the focus of this course is American culture as revealed through the oldest and richest musical traditions of the nation. Musical ability is not a requirement, but an enthusiastic attitude toward the subject is a must. In addition, I’ll strongly encourage singing and other forms of musical expression as learning tools throughout the course, while active participation in these activities (though much appreciated) will not be mandatory. Criteria which will be mandatory, however, include coming on time, being prepared, participating in class discussions and activities, having a good attitude and displaying a healthy respect for our learning environment.

课程教师信息
With more than a decade of teaching experience in Chinese and American universities, Randy Abel is a seasoned and inspired instructor of written and spoken English. His education background includes studies of literature and history, and he hails from the U.S. state of Ohio.

课程编码：15MGX024H 英文名称：English in the Professional Environment 课时：16 学分：0.50 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Angus Black

教学目的要求
The course looks at the requirements of Engineering, Science and Management Academics’ to use English Language during their career development. It includes:
1. Introductions. Introducing yourself and meeting others.
2. How to write a letter in English suitable for a job application or obtaining a suitable position within academia.
3. How to prepare for interviews.
4. Understanding the culture of the foreign interviewer and how to read the Interviewers personality traits.
5. Making an essay suitable to describe your study work. To highlight what the main theme of your major is.
6. Presenting your Essay for discussion.
7. Being able to talk after a conference, to meet and increase your social network.
8. Debating a subject not easily defined. The meaning of colours.

预修课程

教材
Class slides will be provided through class QQ group. Books will be provided in ebook form on the subject of writing letters, handling tough interview questions and writing skills with readings.

主要内容
All students are required to attend classes and submit homework by the due date.

Homework will be provided based on the ability to complete work during class. Time is provided in class for homework, however if the demand is for more discussion on the subject or student is not able to complete work within the allotted time then in class work will be extended to home by this.

Based on attendance, class presentation and class essay.
Each student gets a 100-based grade from the summer course.
1 point is deducted from assessed score for each lesson missed. Also ½ point deducted for late attendance. Total 5 points will be deducted for time keeping. This may be recovered by providing evidence of reading class notes and doing homework given during the missed class.
Assessment will be made during class based on:-
• participation, 20 points
• the production of a job application letter, 20 points
• preparing an essay on a major, 20 points
• making preparations for an interview 20 points
• debating innovative ideas. 20 points

Class slides will include adequate notes for full understanding of lessons given. Ebooks are provided for study and further revision work, if student feels more understanding or revision is required. Students will be encouraged to participate in class. A target of 90% class participation is encouraged.

课程名称: 大生物医学数据分析导论
英文名称: Introduction to Analysis of Big Biomedical Data
详细内容:
大生物医学数据分析导论

课程编码：011M7005H 英文名称：Introduction to Analysis of Big Biomedical Data 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：周晓华

教学目的要求
This course will introduce a variety of statistical methods for analysis of biomedical big data. The era of big data has arrived. The amount of data for each individual is huge and may include data from next-generation sequencing technology, wearable devices for measuring exposures and physical activities on subjects, new neurogenetic and neuroscientific measuring devices for recording brain activity, and electronic medical records and administrative databases that record a variety of demographic, longitudinal and billing information. Availability of these data sources brings much promise to the medical science. However, the big data will come with their own particular issues involving bias, confounding, study design and reproducibility. How to best analyze big data will be a big issue. In this course, I will introduce these issues and statistical methods for addressing these issues

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Lecture 1: Introduction and Regression for Big Data
Lecture 2: Variable Selection and Regularization
Lecture 3: Classification for Big Data
Lecture 4: Ensemble Learning & Tree Methods
Lecture 5: Dimension Reduction Method
Lecture 6: High Dimensional Inference
Lecture 7: Cluster Analysis

参考文献

课程教师信息
周晓华博士是美国华盛顿大学生物统计系教授，同时是该校医学院精神病和行为科学系兼职教授。
周晓华博士也是美国国家老年痴呆合作研究中心（NACC) 副主任， 美国联邦政府退伍军人事务部西雅图医疗中心医学统计研究室主任, 美国联邦政府退伍军人事务部统计学家学会会长。 1999年当选为国际统计研究院(ISI)选举会士(Elected Member)。2004年他当选为美国统计学会(ASA) 会士(Fellow)，曾任美国统计学会流行病统计分会主席; 卫生政策统计分会主席.， 流行病统计分会主席, 精神健康统计分会主席，现任国际生物统计学会中国分会理事长，美国联邦政府食品和药物管理局 （FDA）医疗器械和放射健康顾问委员会成员，世界中医药学会联合会临床疗效评价专业委员会副会长。2001年他与Hirano, Imbens和 Rubin教授一起，获得Bayes分析国际组织与ASA的Bayes统计学组的Mitchell奖，2007年被美国联邦政府退伍军人事务部授予研究生涯科学家奖 (Career Scientist Award)的荣誉称号. 2008获的中国国家自然科学基金委杰出海外青年基金 (杰青B类). 2010 获的中国教育部海外名师称号, 2011获的中国教育部海外高层次文教专家称号。 他曾是期刊Statistical Sinica， Biometrics 副编辑, 目前是 Statistics in Medicine，Journal of the American Statistical Association – Theory and Method Section 副编辑。 周晓华博士的研究主要集中于在在卫生经济，卫生服务，医学检验，中医科学，试验中存在缺失数据和非依从性的因果推断分析领域发展新的统计方法。 已在国际审查期刊上出版了220篇SCI文章。2002年他与另外两名学者合作完成了诊断医学方面第一本综合性统计著作“Statistical Methods in Diagnostic Medicine”，该书第二版已于2012年出版。

教学目的要求
Statistical machine learning is an interdisciplinary research area which is closely related to statistics, computer sciences, engineering, artificial intelligence, and bioinformatics. Many statistical machine learning techniques and algorithms are very useful for various scientific areas. In particular, modern technology enables us to gather data in large volume and complexity. Analysis of such data efficiently and effectively is becoming increasingly critical. Statistical machine learning tools have been proven to be very effective in solving many such problems. The goal of this short course is to provide a comprehensive overview of statistical machine learning methods and some recent research developments in machine learning.

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Topics include basics of statistical learning, classical methods as well as modern techniques including sparse shrinkage methods such as LASSO, Support Vector Machines, Boosting, Generalized Additive Models, and more. Various application examples will be discussed as well.

课程名称: 高维生物统计数据分析
详细内容:
高维生物统计数据分析

课程编码：011M7006H 英文名称：Analysis of High-Dimensional Biostatistical Data 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：马双鸽

教学目的要求
Biostatistics is an important subfield of statistics. The relevant scientific areas include clinical trials, genetics, public health, biomedicine, and others. Many recently collected biostatistical data are high dimensional, with the number of variables potentially far exceeding the sample size. In addition, many biostatistical datasets do not have interchangeable variables, and it is critical to model the interconnections among variables and account for such interconnections in modeling.

预修课程
advanced statistical estimation and inference; basic biology; statistical computing.

教材

主要内容
In this lecture series, I will introduce statistical methods designed for the analysis of high-dimensional biostatistical data. The main topics to be covered will include:
1. Background on biomedical studies that generate high-dimensional data. Special attention will be paid to cancer genetic data.
2. Individual variable based marginal analysis. The focus will be on multiple comparison adjustment.
3. Individual variable based joint analysis. Both dimension reduction and variable selection methods will be introduced.
4. System-based analysis including group analysis and network-based analysis.
5. Special topics including robust analysis methods and interaction analysis.
The lectures will cover methodology, computation, and application. Important theoretical results will also be discussed.

英文名称: Gauge Field Theory and Index Theorem
详细内容:
规范场论和指标定理

课程编码：021M7004H 英文名称：Gauge Field Theory and Index Theorem 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：杨富中等

教学目的要求
本课程为理论物理和数学物理专业博士、硕士研究生的专业强化课。主要内容为纤维丛的几何学，示性类，指标定理，及其与量子场论的关系。通过本课程学习，希望学生能掌握物理学中的现代几何与拓扑方法，为从事专业研究打好基础。

预修课程

教材
Bo-Yu Hou and Bo-yuan Hou，Differential Geometry for Physicists，World Scientific，1997.

主要内容
第一章 纤维丛的几何，Yang-Mills理论
主丛及其伴丛的联络、曲率，矢量丛的联络、曲率，规范场的作用量及场方程，磁单极和瞬子解。
第二章 示性类
障碍论及应用，Weil同态，陈类和陈特征，分裂原理，flag 流形, flag 丛，Euler类，Pontrjagin类，Stiefel-Whitney类，Chern-Simons形式。
第三章 Atiyah-Singer 指标定理
Euler数的组合、拓扑和分析含义，椭圆微分算子的符号、拓扑指标和解析指标的内蕴定义，指标定理的K-理论形式和上同调形式，各种经典椭圆算子及其指标，扭曲椭圆复形，瞬子模空间的维数计算，指标定理的热核和超对称证明简介。
第四章 G-指标定理及其应用
等变上同调群，等变 K-理论, 局部化原理, 椭圆 G-微分算子的指标定理: K-理论形式和上同调形式，Lefschetz 不动点定理及其推广, G-指标定理的应用。
第五章 簇指标定理，带边流形和开无限流形上的指标定理
η-不变量,行列丛的几何, Dirac算子的簇指标定理，APS指标定理，谱边界条件，自旋复形的APS指标定理，开无限流形上的指标定理，Dirac算子的弱局域边界条件。
第六章 规范理论的几何与拓扑性质
规范和引力反常的拓扑结构, 整体引力反常和例外微分结构, 量子反常的上同调分析，瞬子模空间，拓扑场论简介，Seiberg-Witten理论简介。

参考文献

1, S. Morita: Geometry and Differential Forms
2, Weiping Zhang, Chern-Weil Theory and Witten Deformation.
3. S. Kobayashi, K. Nomizu, Foundations of Differential Geometry，Vol.1,2, Interscience Publishers，New York，1969;
4, B.A.Dubrovin，etc., Modern Geometry，Part Ⅰ(1984)，Part Ⅱ(1985)，Part Ⅲ (1990)，Springer-Verlag; Husemoller, Fibre Bundles, Springer-Verlag, 1983
5, P. Shanahan, The Atiyah-Singer index theorem : an introduction. Berlin ; Springer-Verlag, 1978.

课程编码：02MGX004H 英文名称：Communication Skills 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：叶先扬

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Chapter 1. Introduction
Communication is a basic life skill, as important as the skills by which you make your way through school or earn a living. Your ability to communicate largely determines your happiness and success. When you communicate effectively, you make and keep friends. You are valued at work . Your children respect and trust you.

Chapter 2. Basic Skills
a. Listening--Active, Paraphrasing, Clarifying and Giving Feedback.
b. Self-Disclosure--Self-disclosure may be as scary to you as skydiving without a parachute.
c. Expressing--The four kinds of expressing:
1.Observations, ( This is the language of the scientist, the detective, the appliance repair person).
2.Thoughts, ( Your thoughts are conclusions, inferences drawn from what you have heard, read, and observed).
3.Feelings, ( Probably the most difficult part of communication is expressing your feelings, some people don’t want to hear what you feel).
4.Needs, ( No one knows what you want except you. Youare the expert, the highest authority, on yourself. However, you may have a heavy injunction against expressing your needs).
Chapter 3. Body Language
a. Body movement--
b. Facial Expression--
c. Gestures—
d. Spatial relationships—
Chapter 4. Assertiveness Training
A. Assertiveness training teaches you to express your feelings, thoughts, and wishes, and to stand up for your legitimate rights without violating the rights of others.
Assertiveness is a skill you can acquire, not a personality trait that some people are born with and others are not.
You might have no trouble being assertive with your family, yet find it almost impossible to be assertive with strangers.
B. Responding to Criticism
One of the major reasons people have difficulty being assertiveis that they experience criticism as rejection. This is often a leftover from childhood, when you faced criticism from a one-down position.
There are three good strategies for assertively responding to criticism: acknowledgement, clouding, and probing.
1.Acknowledgement—
2.Clouding—
3. Probing—
Chapter 5. Negotiation
Everybody negotiates—not just union officials, diplomats, and contractors. You negotiate when you ask for a raise, apply for a job, dispute a grade with a teacher, buy a car or a house, sue somebody, or ask your landlord to paint your apartment. Any time you want something from someone who may have conflicting interests, you are potentially in a negotiating situation.
Negotiation is a skill that helps you get what you want from others without alienating them.

Four stages of negotiation :

1. Preparation—
2. Discussion—
3. Proposal and counterproposal—
4. Agreement/disagreement—
Dealing With Conflict--
Your attitude toward conflict will determine your success at negotiation. Conflict is inevitable, no matter how you try to avoid it
Rules of Principled Negotiation:
1. Separate the People from the Problem—
2. Understand the People—
3. List Options
Chapter 6. Social Skills
Making Contact—This chapter is about breaking the ice and making conversation with the people who attract you.
Reframe Your Approach Behavior—
Reframe Rejection—
Deal with the Emotional Blow When Rejected—Guidelines For Making Contact—
How to make contact ?
1. Use Body Language—
2. Use Icebreakers—
3. Ask for information
The Art of Conversation :
Once you break the ice, the question is how to make satisfying contact with other person. You only have to know how to do three things to make good conversation: ask questions, listen actively, and disclose a little about yourself.

Chapter 7 Family Skills
Successful relationships does not just happen. They are nurtured by the people in them. A strong relationship is based on the couple paying attention to the way the relationship is going, and making changes in how they interact together based on what the relationship needs to keep it healthy.
What makes a good relationship ?

Communicating with Children :
To be an effective parent is to realize two things: that you are a human being with problems and that your children are human beings with problems.
There are three critical communication skills required for effective parenting: Listening, Expressing, and Joint problem Solving. These are applicable whether your child is a three-year-old or a teenger.

Chapter 8 Public Skills
A. Influencing Others—
B. Public Speaking—Effective public speaking requires special communication skills.
C. Interviewing—You will very likely be interviewed many times in your life
D. Make Meetings Work
In business, meetings are a fact of life.
In Summary:
• Without proper preparation, meetings can be a waste of time.
• Agendas are critical to keeping a meeting on track and keeping all participants informed.
• Invite only the necessary people to meetings to keep the group focused and active.
• When leading a meeting, speak with energy, tone variability, and hand gestures.
• Listen carefully and completely before preparing to disagree with someone.
• At the end of the meeting, summarize all the actions or decisions that were made to be sure everyone is in agreement.

H. Berke’s fundamental research activities cover various fields of organometallic chemistry. Major efforts are devoted to the area of transition metal hydrides, which is related to homogeneous catalysis, in particular homogeneous hydrogenations and hydrosilations. Metal carbon oriented activities concern several catalyses of C-C coupling reactions mediated by transition metal complexes and in addition metallacumulenes, where carbon chained units are sought to space transition metal centers for potential use as single-electron devices. Another research field deals with the archaeometry of ancient, manmade blue and purple pigments.

课程编码：041M7003H 英文名称：Polymer Physics 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：韩志超

教学目的要求

预修课程
1)Physical Chemistry;
2)Calculus;
3)Introduction to Polymers is preferred.
4)Some knowledge on differential equation, linear algebra and Fourier Transformation are preferred.

教材

主要内容
I.Introduction to Single Chain, Ideal Chain, and Real Chain:
Freely jointed chain, freely rotating chain, restricted rotation, worm-like chain, rotational isomeric state (RIS), Theta-solvent, good solvent, excluded volume, bulk system, blob model.
II.Chain Dynamics and Thermodynamics:
Chain dynamics, intrinsic viscosity, rheology, viscoelasticity and WLF equation; Flory-Huggins theory, osmotic pressure.
III.Scattering, Dynamics and Kinetics (I)
Scattering and reciprocal space (Fourier or q- space); Light scattering, X-ray and Neutron scattering; Space-time correlation, dynamic light scattering and relationship with diffusion, viscoelastic properties of polymers, Rouse and Zimm models.
IV.Scattering, Dynamics and Kinetics (II)
Phase separation and phase separation kinetics, spinodal decomposition.

2.Course Outline
Name of course: ORGANOMETALLIC CHEMISTRY
Aims: This course aims to provide students with an understanding of the main principles of organometallic chemistry and the synthesis, structure and reactivity of organometallic complexes.
Learning Outcomes: At the end of this module students should:
Know the methods of preparation, relative stability and reactivity of metal-carbonyls, -alkyls, -carbenes, -hydrides; as well as alkene, diene, allyl, cyclopentadienyl and benzene complexes.
Know and be able to identify the basic reaction types, substitution, oxidative addition, migratory insertion, reductive elimination.
Be able to use spectroscopic methods in the characterisation of organometallic species.
Know the 18 electron rule and be able to apply it.
Students should be able to select or predict the most suitable spectroscopic or structural methods for the characterisation of a range of organometallic complexes.
Obtain new information from textbooks, describe relevant chemistry and discuss it with peers and teachers, solve problems.
Be able to apply above knowledge to problem solving.
Methods: Lectures (x17) and group problem solving classes (x3).

Kirk Schanze earned his B.S. in Chemistry from Florida State University in 1979 and his Ph.D. in Chemistry from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1983. He was appointed a Miller Postdoctoral Fellow at the University of California, Berkeley, from 1984-1986. He was a faculty member at the University of Florida from 1986 - 2016 where he was Distinguished Professor and Prominski Professor of Chemistry. Starting from August 2016 he will hold the Welch Distinguished University Chair in Chemistry at the University of Texas at San Antonio. He was a Senior Editor of the ACS journal Langmuir from 2000 - 2008. Since 2008, Schanze is Editor-in-Chief of ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, the ACS journal focused on chemistry and engineering of applications-focused research in materials and interfaces.
His research interests are centered in the field of photochemistry and photophysics of molecular, polymer and materials systems. His group is interested in a variety of applications, including fluorescent sensors, dye sensitized solar cells, organic solar cells and light emitting diodes. He has authored or co-authored more than 300 peer-reviewed articles on basic and applied research topics, with a primary focus on organic and organometallic materials chemistry, and is named in 15 patents or disclosures.

课程编码：041M7007H 英文名称：Electroanalytical Chemistry 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：Takeo Ohsaka

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Chemists, biochemists, environmental and material scientists, physicists, medical scientists, etc. and also students in all branches of science as well as analysts always ask questions such as “what is it? “,” how much of it is present? “ and often “how fast does it change ? “. Electrochemistry is an ideal analytical tool for answering each of these questions. Thus, “electroanalytical chemistry” or “electroanalysis” is usually used to mean the use of electrochemistry in an analytical context, i.e., an analyte is studied by in vitro, in vivo and/or ex vivo measuring the potential and/or current in a sample (solution) containing the analyte using various electrochemical techniques. Electroanalytical chemistry is one of today’s fastest growing and most exciting branches of analytical science. Electroanalytical techniques offer a unique access to information on chemical, biochemical and physical systems. This course will provide an introduction to electroanalytical chemistry including the foundations (e.g., the origin and measurements of electrode potentials, equilibrium and dynamic measurements, and electrochemical techniques) as well as the practical applications of electroanalytical chemistry.

课程教师信息
Prof. Ka M. Ng is Chair Professor of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. From 1980-2000, he served as Professor of Chemical Engineering at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. He joined the Hong Kong department in 2000 and served as Head from 2002-2005. He was CEO of the Nano and Advanced Materials Institute Ltd., a government funded R&D center, from 2006-2013. He served as Corporate Science and Technology Advisor for Mitsubishi Chemical, Japan, from 2001 to 2013. He held visiting positions at DuPont, MIT, and the National University of Singapore. His research interests center on product conceptualization, process design and business development involving water, natural herbs, nanomaterials, and various advanced materials. He is an editor / editorial board member of various journals. Professor Ng is the recipient of the General Electric Outstanding Teaching Award. He is a fellow of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers where he received the Excellence in Process Development Research Award in 2002.

课程编码：071M7006H 英文名称：Methods of Imaging Earth's Interior 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：MAARTEN VALENTIJN DE HOOP

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Fundamental components of inverse theory in the solid earth concern (i) spectral perturbation, (ii) linearized
transmission tomography,and(iii)inverse(single) scattering –tiedto reflection tomography.An asymptotic
description of (ii) leads to the geodesic X-ray transform, while an asymptotic description of (iii) leads to
the generalized Radon transform. Surface-wave tomographyand inverse surface-wave scattering yields an
integration of (i) with (ii) and (iii), embedding part of the subsurface in a “half space”.

Thegoalof this courseistoprovideanoverviewof approachesand techniques -associated with time reversal
-to imagingthe materials propertiesand processesinthe earth under(ii)and (iii).We focusondevelopments
in reverse-time migration (RTM), the new notion of array receiver functions, and finite-frequency
transmission&reflection tomography.We discuss applications pertaining to the crust, the transition zone
and thelowermost mantle. The course will consistof16 hoursof lectures anda writtenexam(2 hours).

course material: www.math.purdue.edu/ mdehoop/10
topics
day 1
PART 1 [3 hours]: ray-wave duality.
wave equation, asymptotics
–plane waves, oscillatory integral representations
–method of stationary phase
– geometrical optics, rays.
linearized (transmission) tomography

day 2-3
PART 2 [5 hours]: common source (event), scalar waves.
wave equation (transmission) tomography, sensitivitykernels.
reverse-time migration (RTM) and inverse scattering
–reverse-time continued fields
–resolution, illumination analysis

day 3-4
PART 3 [4 hours]:elastic waves, isotropy & anisotropy.
polarizations(qP, qSV, qSH), polarized “Helmholtz” equations.
RTM-based elastic-wave inverse scattering.
array receiver functions

day 5
PART 4 [3 hours]: multi source, scalar waves.
extended imaging
–caustics and artifacts
–curvilinear coordinates, pseudodepth, DSR condition
–reflection tomography

day 6
PART 5 [1 hour]: remarks on optimization.
least-squares RTM, controlled noise sources, blending.
full waveform inversion (FWI)

EXAM
[2 hours]
(material: PARTS 1-4, OPEN BOOK/PERSONALNOTES)

课程编码：071M7007H 英文名称：Some Numerical Solutions for Seismic Wave Propagation in Complex Media 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：Yann Capdeville

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Some numerical solutions for seismic wave propagation in complex media.
This lecture set is intended to give an overview of some of the older and very recent numerical techniques currently used in seismology to model wave propagation in complex geological media.
Some computer practicals are planed to give to the students a concrete experience about these methods. Students are encouraged to bring their own laptop. If you don’t have any laptop, it is not a big problem as I will show the practical on a screen. A linux system (or an other system with linux in a virtual box (www.virtualbox.org)) is necessary. Having installed tcsh or csh shell, latex (for documentation), xmgrace and/or gnuplot 2-D plotters, awk, GMT plotting tool, gfortran or ifort fortran compiler, mpich library. The practical material will be soon available here: http://www.sciences.univ-nantes.fr/lpgnantes/yannscode
Lecture 1 (3h)
-Introduction to the modeling in seismology and lecture descriptions (1h)
-Introduction to the wave equations in seismology (2h): The wave equations (gravity, elastic, acoustic, coupling). Source, boundary conditions, anisotropy, attenuation, simple solutions ...

Lecture 2 (3h)
-The representation theorem and time reversal in seismology (1.5h)
-Introduction to numerical modeling in seismology in general and to the finite difference method in particular (1.5h)

Lecture 3 (3h)
-Normal mode solution in a 1-D bar and then for the global Earth. Computer practical with the modeslib package.
Lecture 4 (3h)
The spectral element method.
1-D and (maybe) 2-D computer practicals
Lecture 5 (3h)
Homogenization: introduction to small scale problems in seismology and wave propagation issue.
The Backus solution: 1-D 1-D case. Results in 3-D layered media.
Introduction to two scale periodic homogenization in 1-D
Computer practical in 1-D
Lecture 6 (3h)
Introduction to two scale non-periodic homogenization in 1-D
Computer practical in 1-D
Introduction to the two scale homogenization in 2-D and 3-D in the periodic case.
Lecture 7 (2h)
A few words on the general non-periodic case and on residual homogenization.

课程编码：071M7008H 英文名称：Active Tectonics and Rupture Mechanisms of Seismogenic Fault 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：LIN AIMING

教学目的要求
The final goal of the lectures is to deepen the understanding of current tectonic
movement and rupture mechanisms of seismogenic fault.

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Active Tectonics implies that tectonic movements including earthquakes are currently happening or are expected to occur within a future time span, which causes the deformation of the earth’ crust and changes the morphology of landforms. Rupture Mechanisms of Seismogenic Fault is mainly focused on the rupture mechanisms and processes of formation of fault rocks including Earthquake Fossil (pseudotachylyte) and related earthquake materials that form within natural seismogenic fault zones and in high-speed frictional experiments. Throughout this lecture, it is expected to learn the essence and ethic of Active Tectonics and Rupture Mechanisms of Seismogenic Fault.

Contents
1) Introduction
2) Methodology of Active Tectonics and Rupture Mechanisms of Seismogenic
Fault
3) Identification of Active Faults
4) Co-seismic surface ruptures
5) Structural features of thrust, strike-slip and normal faults
6) Tectonic Landforms associated with Active Faulting and Folding
7) Paleoseismology
8) Structural features of seismogenic fault zones
9) Fault rocks and Earthquake Fossils
10) High-speed frictional experiments
11) Seismogenic fault model
Grading
The score is evaluated comprehensively from reports for the lecture (including presence
point) and the final examination.

教学目的要求
近年来，与地震预测有关的科学进展，全面改变了地震预测的理论框架、研究方法、技术路线、社会应用，也使得我国目前关于地震预测问题的科学理解的落后成为一个亟待解决的问题。本课程试图结合文献阅读实践, 为地球科学及物理、数学、高技术、管理科学相关专业的研究生提供与地震预测有关的科学问题、国际进展、研究方法、社会应用方面的基础性、背景性知识，希望能够使不同学科背景的学生通过本课程，特别是通过在本课程中自己的独立思考和判断，对目前地震预测研究的进展、挑战和关键科学问题建立一个较为客观、全面的概念。教学采用授课、文献阅读和讨论相结合的方式。

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Addressed topics



1. Geodesy and Earth remote sensing : general introduction



2. Global properties of the Earth : Topography, gravity and Geoïd, Global surface deformation,



plate tectonics and plates deformation



3. Measuring the Earth deformation : terrestrial and spatial geodesy : a review of present day tools



(leveling, triangulation, SLR, VLBI, DORIS, GPS, Insar, etc…)



4. GPS : How and what for ? Technical and detailed explanations on this tool : basics of the theory



and from network design to data acquisition, processing and modeling



5. Measuring plate tectonics, monitoring faults, and surveying earthquakes with GPS



detailed contain of lessons



1. Introduction to Geodesy

• Terrestrial geodesy

• Physical geodesy: Gravity field and Geoïd. definition of altitude

• Measurement of the Geoïd and Earth gravity field (Satellite Laser Ranging, satellite gravimetry

and altimetry)

• physical processes associated to gravity



2. Monitoring the Earth surface from space

• Pictures of the surface from optical Imagery, i.e. obtained by telescopes or cameras operating in

visual bandwith.

• Shape of the surface from radar imagery

• Surface deformation from space/satellite geodesy : SLR, VLBI, DORIS, GPS, INSAR



3. Basics of GPS measurements : uncertainties/precision/errors

• what kind of noise/errors/uncertainties/un-modeled things affect the GPS precision : AS, SA,

orbits, clocks, ionosphere, troposphere, antenna phase centers, centering (tribrachs), etc...

• how do we evaluate GPS uncertainties ? (difference between formal and a posteriori) can we

trust them ?

• difference between precision and accuracy (internal consistency like repeatability is assertion of

precision, comparison with other method affected by different biases is accuracy)

• reference frames : how do we map ? with what precision ? What influence on results ?

• Elements of GPS data processing, using GAMIT software



4. Rigid plate tectonics: motion and deformation

• Plate definition

• Plate motion : Euler pole

• Geological model : Nuvel-1A

• Geodetic model : ITRF

• Rigid plate rotations

• Plate deformation : strain and rotation tensors



5. Deformation pattern in elastic medium

• Stress and force in 2D

• Strain : normal and shear

• Elastic medium equations

• Vertical fault in elastic medium => arctangent

• General elastic dislocation (Okada’s formulas)

• Fault examples: continental strike-slip faulting in SE-Asia, subduction in Indonesia, Japan and

Chile



6. The seismic cycle

• Elastic accumulation and rupture on a fault. Example on a Strike-slip fault and a Subduction

fault

• Size of an earthquake

• Time dependent station motion and earthquake cycle : READ and Wallace models

• Pre-seismic, co-seismic and post-seismic motions

• Triggering of earthquake

• Precursors ?

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
构造层次的概念与问题。构造地质学三大难题：低角正断层，高角逆断层与宽V形共轭走滑断层(wide-open V-shaped conjugate strike-slip faults)。变质核杂岩与伸展拆离断层。韧性组构的发育和运动学、动力学含义。挤出构造(extrusion tectonics）与渠流理念（channel flow）。走滑挤压与走滑拉张构造与变（位）形分解作用。构造地质学的新理论—岩石变形的最大有效力矩准则。运动学涡度的理论与实践。造山作用与晚造山伸展垮塌作用。

第1讲：构造地质的历史和现状、基础应变理论回顾。

第5讲：韧性组构的形成、发育。
第6讲：低角度正断层、变质核杂岩及片麻岩穹隆。
第7讲：大型逆冲断层。

微量元素地球化学

课程编码：072M7007H 英文名称：Rare Earth Element Geochemistry 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：刘树文

教学目的要求
微量元素是指自然界中通常丰度低于1%或0.1%，并用现代分析技术可检测出的所有化学元素。微量元素地球化学是研究自然物质和自然体系中微量元素的分布规律、存在形式、活动特点、控制因素及其地球化学意义的地球化学分支。本课程主要介绍元素分类和不同类型微量元素的特征、分馏和分布规律及其控制因素，包括微量元素地球化学的热力学基础、微量元素的分配系数及其控制因素、微量元素温度计、年代计、岩浆作用中微量元素的行为和微量元素示踪等，使学生初步掌握微量元素地球化学的基本理论和方法，分析流体与岩浆活动过程中微量元素的溶解、沉淀与结晶过程，通过微量元素行为解释岩石和矿床的成因及构造背景等。
Introduction
Trace elements are elements with abundance usually lower than 1% or 0.1% in natural systems, and these elements can be determined by the modern analytical equipments. Trace element geochemistry is an important subdiscipline of the geochemistry field, which mainly studies distribution, existence forms, active feature, controlling factors in the natural materials and systems, comprising the thermodynamic basement of the trace element geochemistry, partition coefficients of the trace elements and their controlling factors, trace element thermometers, dating for minerals and rocks, analyzing dissolution and precipitation and crystallization of the trace elements and so on, leading students initially to know essential principle and methods of the trace element geochemistry and to analyze and interpret the genesis of the fluids, rocks and deposits and their tectonic setting of formations.

全球大地构造学

课程编码：072M7009H 英文名称：Global Tectonics 课时：32 学分：1.50 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：TIMOTHY MICHAEL KUSKY等

教学目的要求
This class will provide a quantitative assessment of the structure of the lithosphere and its division into a number of torsionally rigid plates, each moving independently of each other. We will examine the geometry of plate boundaries in two and three dimensions. We will discuss the geometry and evolution of divergent, convergent, and transform boundaries, and discuss the nature of the forces involved in plate deformation, and the mechanics of the different types of plate boundaries. Types of sedimentary basins that form in different plate tectonic settings will be compared, and their thermal histories discussed, and regional metamorphism associated with different tectonic settings will be briefly examined. The stability, geometry, and geologic effects of triple junctions and their migration will be examined, and the nature and origin of Large Igneous Provinces, mantle plumes, and hot spot tracks will be presented.

预修课程

教材

主要内容
The plate tectonic paradigm has revolutionized geologic thinking, providing us with a tool with which to make quantifiable, testable hypotheses about geological processes and the evolution of geological terranes. We talk confidently about the past positions and arrangements of continents and oceans for much of geological time, and we are striving toward understanding the planetary mechanisms that drive these plate motions. Plate tectonics has also provided us with a framework within which to understand the mechanics of plate interactions such as the collision of India with Asia, subduction beneath the western Americas, and sea floor spreading. In this class we will first examine how we know these things and, more importantly, how to discuss them quantitatively-- cm/yr, latitude, longitude vs time, angular rotations, millions of years before present, etc.



This class will provide a quantitative assessment of the structure of the lithosphere and its division into a number of torsionally rigid plates, each moving independently of each other. We will examine the geometry of plate boundaries in two and three dimensions. We will discuss the geometry and evolution of divergent, convergent, and transform boundaries, and discuss the nature of the forces involved in plate deformation, and the mechanics of the different types of plate boundaries. Types of sedimentary basins that form in different plate tectonic settings will be compared, and their thermal histories discussed, and regional metamorphism associated with different tectonic settings will be briefly examined. The stability, geometry, and geologic effects of triple junctions and their migration will be examined, and the nature and origin of Large Igneous Provinces, mantle plumes, and hot spot tracks will be presented.


Topics

Introduction and global overview
Rules of Plate Motion: Plate Kinematics
Structure of plate boundaries
Continental rifts, hot spots, mantle plumes, and LIP’s
The sea floor, and rifting to sea-floor spreading
History of Continental drift and plate tectonics: Ocean ridges and transforms, animations
ophiolites
ancient ophiolites
Convergent boundaries, subduction zones
accretionary prisms, convergent basins
Sumatra earthquake and tsunami
continental collisions: Continental Transforms
Tibet tectonics and Wenchuan earthquake
Precambrian tectonics and the supercontinent cycle
Final Exam


Grades will be based on the class participation and a final exam.

课程编码：073M7002H 英文名称：Global Land Atmosphere Interaction Dynamics (GLAD) 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：0009427

教学目的要求
To provide an introduction to the role of land in weather and climate systems, and to transition the students from taking a class to doing scientific research.

预修课程
Basic calculus and physics and an interest in interdisciplinary processes.

教材

主要内容
Topics:
Basics of terrestrial surface energy, water and carbon balances.
Micrometeorology and atmospheric boundary layer.
Ecohydrology, biometeorology, hydrometeorology, and hydroclimatology.
Theory, modeling, and observations.
Spatial scales: point scale (meters) to global.
Temporal scales: seconds to centuries.
Expectations:
At the end of the semester, the students are expected to be knowledgeable about the frontier research topics facing the scientific community and society, such as the global water/energy/carbon cycles, the relative contributions to climate change due to increases in greenhouse gases and changes in land use/land cover, the impacts of urbanization and deforestation on the atmosphere and climate, and the impacts of climate change on water resources, ecosystems, and the environment. Although the students are not required to run state-of-the-art land surface models, they will need to know how these models can be used to answer science questions, they will learn how to design numerical experiments, interpret results from (say) the NCAR Community Land Model (Diagnostics), understand the sources of observations (e.g., flux tower measurements and satellite remote sensing), write scientific reports, and make scientific presentations. Graduate students need to read and comment on cutting-edge research articles in the literature.
Specific Topics:
1. Land as a component of the Earth system
2. Global energy, water, and carbon cycles
3. Global scale influences on hydrological processes
4. Thermodynamics
5. Atmospheric boundary layer
6. Soil physics
7. Hillslope processes and watershed hydrology
8. Leaf, canopy, plant functional type and vegetation dynamics
9. Land–climate interactions
10. Land use and land cover change
11. Modeling discussions and literature review
12. Presentations

课程编码：071M7009H 英文名称：Advanced Course on Mathematical Geoscience 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：徐培亮

教学目的要求
在科学研究中,我们总是会面临两个基本问题: [1] 实验数据中有没有未知的新知识?新现象（如物理的/化学的）；[2]如何作出新的数学理论/方法,或者如何利用现有的数学理论/方法从实验数据中最有效,最可靠,最精确地把有用的信息提取出来.我们的课程将主要集中于第二个问题.随着地空观测技术的巨大进步,现有的数学理论/方法可能已经不能满足我们的需要.另一方面,随着科学技术的发展,我们可能发现某一学科的数学基础理论可能不完美,有缺陷,需要更新.我们本数学地球科学高级强化课程的主要目的就是要学生学习如何利用利用现有的数学理论/方法解决自己的问题,必要时,如何作出新的数学理论/方法去解决自己的问题.

对于一个科学或者工程问题,我们都必须直接面对如下几个问题:[1]模型恰不恰当? 模型还需不需要改进? 模型/数据组合是否匹配? [2]实验观测数据是否有异常值?如果实验观测数据包含异常值怎么办? 怎么才能保证实验结果不受异常值的影响? [3]现实的科学或者工程问题一般都是非线性的,可能有多个局部最优解,怎么才能保证得到正确的全部最优解? [4]一般说来,我们不能对我们感兴趣的量/信息进行直接量测或者直接观测,而只能通过间接观测求解.这样的问题经常是不适定问题,就是说,其解可能不存在,不唯一,或者不稳定.对于这样的问题,我们怎么才能从实验观测数据最有效,最可靠,最精确地得到我们感兴趣的量/信息? [5]在地球科学或者其它科学/工程问题中,我们可能需要利用不同类型的数据进行求解,怎么才能对各种不同实验观测数据进行同化或者联合处理?

预修课程

教材

主要内容
我们的课程将针对这些问题进行讲授.主要内容如下:
1. Linear and Nonlinear Models: From Concepts to Advanced Estimation Theory
2. Linear and Nonlinear Filtering: From Concepts to Advanced Filtering Theory
3. Nonlinear Filtering: Recent Approximate Analytical Methods
4. Nonlinear Bayesian Filtering: Numerical Methods
5. Local optimization, simulated annealing and genetic algorithm for nonlinear nonconvex problems
6. Global optimization for nonlinear nonconvex problems: A hybrid method
7. Outliers and Robust Estimation
8. Sign-constrained Robust Least Squares, Subjective Breakdown Points and the Effect of Weights of Observations on Robustness
9. Combining different kinds of data in linear inverse ill-posed models
10. Total least squares and/or Measurement-based Perturbation Theory

课程编码：071M7011H 英文名称：Astrobiology: The Origin, Evolution and Future of Life in the Universe 课时：20 学分：1.00 课程属性：高级强化课 主讲教师：李一良

教学目的要求

预修课程

教材

主要内容
Astrobiology: The Origin, Evolution and Future of Life in the Universe

Summary
Are we alone? Is our Earth, the tiny blue star in this infinite Universe the only harbor for life? This oldest philosophical question frequently appears in scientific fictions and now becomes a science. Astrobiology concerns the study of the origin, evolution and destiny of life in the Universe. The emergence of this science is the natural outcome of the great advances in astronomy, biology and geology. The development of molecular biology has revealed the unitary origin and DNA-coding of all life on Earth, despite the great diversity after a long Darwinian evolution. Geologists dated the origin of life back to almost 3.8 billion years ago. Planetary explorations in our solar system have indicated abundant life materials being stored in the planetesimal zone and beyond. Furthermore, the detection of exoplanets has practically extended life exploration to the deep Universe. The astrobiological studies can be classified into cosmic, planetary, ecosystematic scales on a space dimension and, stellar and interstellar evolution, chemical evolution of prelife on Earth and modern ecosystem on a time dimension. Stellar nucleosynthesis and the evolution of galactic chemistry tell us about the formation of life-essential elements such as H, C-O-N-S-P and Fe-peaked transition metals. So, believe it or not, the elements in our body are much older than Earth! The breakthrough in exoplanet detection is a great step in searching a second life and scientists began to develop techniques to examine the atmosphere composition of Earth-like exoplanets. Based on our understanding of life origin on Earth, a body of liquid water, enough carbon and a silicate crust on a planet with a right distance to its sun are enough premises to make a planet habitable. When those conditions are met, life may start in hundred million years or even shorter time. We understand now that life deeply changes the surface spheres of Earth and our current atmosphere is pretty much the result of biological respiration. We also wonder that the great events happened on Earth, such as the appearance of free oxygen, the starting of plate tectonics, the appearance of ice ages, planet-wide formation of banded iron may have either stimulated the evolution of life, or on the contrary, resulted in mass extinction. Now we are on a fast lane going forward but have a quite unpredictable future. How long can our Gaia last? Can our offspring find another oasis in the Universe? Astrobiology cannot answer these questions but will give you a way to think about them.

Questions
1. Is the appearance of life the inevitable result of universe evolution?
2. Are we the purpose of evolution?

Teaching and Learning Plan
Teaching is made of 7 3-hour lectures. Students will read 10 related articles and write one course essay.

Method: MOOC.

Abstracts for Topics

From Big Bang to the molecules of life: Evolution of the universe predates both the chemical evolution and the evolution of life. We summarise the origin of the critical elements for life, the CHNOPS, and the initial formation of molecules. From cosmological models we can un-derstand the origin of hydrogen and helium. Later hydrogen will be required when water is formed. Helium, which appears quite useless for life, turns out to be a critical factor in the synthesis of carbon leading to heavier elements. The second compound of water, oxygen, is formed in the hot cores of stars. Once these elements are blown into the cool interstellar space they begin forming interstellar clouds, where a vast spectrum of molecules is formed. The ob-served properties of these molecules, and the larger dust particles will be reviewed. These play an important role in the formation of planets in the accretion disks of a metal rich population of stars. This material reprocessed by the newly formed star and other planets “rains” on the young planet in the form of meteorites, comets and asteroids creating a supply of raw materi-als needed for the prebiotic evolution and the eventual biological evolution of life.

Questions
1. How old is every part of your body?
2. How to understand you are part of the cosmic evolution?
3. What’s the chronology of the appearance/evolution of every part of your body? For exam-ple, the appearance of elements, cells, biofunctions, organs etc.

Building a Planet: The most natural environment for the existence of life and its development is a planet orbiting a star. The planet Earth is the only one as we know it, circling around the Sun with life on it. There are quite a few conditions which need to be satisfied for life to emerge on our planet. This talk focuses on the more basic question of how planetary systems form and evolve. We adopt a methodology which proves itself to be powerful and successful in the field of stellar evolution, which means, we make use of the fact that there are many stars with their planetary systems in the sky in different stages of their evolution. By observ-ing them and building models we can reconstruct the time sequence and find out the most plausible scenarios for planet formation. There are more than 200 mature fully developed plan-etary systems detected and numerous examples of protoplanetary discs, which are believed to be the sites where planets are born. The life history of our planetary system is concisely re-viewed. We will go over how our Solar System was born, starting from the molecular cloud collapse, after passing through a deeply embedded protostellar phase and successively through a T Tauri phase. Next, we will watch how planetesimals and protoplanets form in protoplane-tary discs via sedimentation and agglomeration until the final system arises after 4.6 mld years of its evolution. The Hubble Space Telescope, the Spitzer Space Telescope, the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope, among other missions and instruments, helped us to put together the dif-ferent stages of this scenario. At the end of this lecture we consider briefly also what will happen with a planetary system, like our own, during further evolution of the central star, when the star enters a Red Giant phase and finally become a white dwarf.

Questions:
1. How do you understand the first life is hyperthermophile?
2. How long you think it has taken to cook the first cell?

Prebiotic Chemistry: Before life could arise on a planet, atoms have to organise themselves into complex biological molecules such as proteins, RNA, or DNA. Such elaborated structures can’t appear by themselves at once, they result from a complex chemical evolution, starting with the simplest organic compounds. At some point, at some not-yet-defined stage of com-plexity and organisation of matter, an important step is made and chemistry turns into biology.

This lecture is devoted to the study of prebiotic chemistry; it focuses on the very first steps of the chemical evolution: the synthesis of the building blocks of the molecular engine of any known living organism on Earth. In a previous lecture of this series, how atoms form in stars was explained. Now we consider how atoms can spontaneously combine to make molecules, before discussing the molecular evolution to cellular life in the next lecture.

In the first part of this lecture living systems are dismantled into more elemental fragments: organic molecules. To address the origin of life, the next question would be how those frag-ments can be synthesized in an abiotic manner. After a short historical review about the chem-istry of life different tracks are explored: an endogenous production of the molecules of life, within the Earth atmosphere or in the depths of primitive oceans, or an exogenous source of prebiotic molecules through space delivery via meteorites and comets. The chemical pathways of synthesis of the building blocks of life will then be described.

Questions
1. DNA first or metabolism first?
2. Describe the history of a C atom, from its synthesis in a star to its incorporation into a liv-ing system on an imaginary planet harbouring life.
3. Describe the extent to which RNA molecules could be considered living systems.

From Molecular Evolution to Cellular Life: First, the essential features of cellular life will be considered; what is required for life, and what are the criteria of life. Nucleic acids, genetic code and its expression system are conserved and ubiquitous properties of all life forms, and therefore are assumed to be the most original functional units of life. Molecular analysis of these structures gives suggestions of how they may have been involved in the early molecular evolution, and what functions they may have provided to the early (precellular) replicators. By going backwards, step by step, one sees which inventions had to precede each stage of early evolution: genetically encoded proteins had to exist prior to the establishment of the Last Universal Common Ancestor (LUCA), and RNA-mediated RNA-replication, or so called RNA world, had to predate genetically encoded proteins. Some cellular RNA-molecules, which have different enzymatic activities and are highly conserved between different organ-isms are supposed to be relicts from this era. Still, many questions related to the early molecu-lar evolution remain open. We do not know, for instance, the prebiotic synthesis routes for the nucleotides, how life chose to use the distinct nucleotides and amino acids in their distinct chiralic forms, how the first functional polynucleotides were assembled, or how the earliest life forms were confined.

Questions
1. What are the difficulties in understanding of the origin of life?
2. What are the building blocks of life and how do they assemble to make functional cells?
3. What are the putative steps required for the establishment of self-sustainable life?
4. What kind of conditions might have driven the prebiotic molecular evolution towards life?
5. How do you define the beginning of life?

Mineral-Organic Molecule Interactions: Prebiotic chemistry plays a central role in the inves-tigation of the possible scenarios of the early chemical environments. Its goal is to shed light on the events involved in the synthesis of initial biomolecules and on the self-organization processes that led the last common ancestor. Even though a well defined scenario for the physico-chemical conditions on the primitive Earth is not available, one can assume that a syn-thetic pathway, in order to be considered prebiotic, should use the simplest chemicals and the most common conditions present at that time. Low molecular weight molecules such as carbon dioxide, hydrogen cyanide, formamide and formaldehyde, easily formed from the primitive atmosphere by ultraviolet light, heat or electric discharge as energy sources, have been consid-ered as prebiotic precursors. The catalysis played a crucial role in the prebiotic synthesis of biomolecules starting from these chemical precursors. Several minerals and metal oxides char-acterized by chemical, redox and photochemical catalytic properties were widely diffused on the primitive Earth. These compounds, when components of a reaction mixture, could have enhanced the efficacy of prebiotic syntheses, affecting the selectivities of the reactions and furnishing local microenvironments able either to concentrate dilute reagents or to preserve newly formed biomolecules from degradative processes. In this lecture we will focus on the main concepts of catalysis applied to prebiotic chemistry, including homogeneous and hetero-geneous catalysis, multifunctional catalysis and autocatalysis. Different examples on the role of catalysis in the synthesis of biomolecules starting from simple precursors will be discussed with a special attention to the synthesis of sugars, peptides and oligonucleotides. Examples of prebiotic synthesis of biomolecules with non terrestrial minerals as well as multi-components catalysis will be also described.

Questions
1. What’s your understanding of “clay gene? Do you believe that the mineral surface have catalyzed the syntheses of prebiotic molecules?
2. What’s the role of silicates for a habitable planet?

The Ancestors of Protein: In searching the origin of life it is possible to apply two different approaches. The first one is a down-to-top approach, in which, starting from inanimated mat-ter, like for instance basic organic compounds or amino acids, one tries to reproduce the pro-cesses and the conditions that gave birth to the first living beings about 3.85 Ga ago. Alterna-tively, one may attempt to extract hints about the first steps of the evolution of life from the observation of present organisms. This top-down approach is based on the fact that all living forms have a common ancestor, so that it is licit to assume that some of its vestiges are still preserved inside the genetic code of current cells and bacteria. Indeed, it is well known that there are structures inside proteins, like structural motifs and folds, which seem to be intimate-ly connected with evolution. For example, while there are about 100,000 expressed proteins in eukariotic systems, there are much fewer motifs and folds, a fact that is related to the path-ways of evolution. In this lecture some aspects of the top-down approach will be illustrated. After a brief review of the known structures in proteins and other macromolecules which are relevant for life, a discussion will follow about the physical and chemical properties of biopol-ymers. Physical and chemical laws were in fact present during the period in which life started on the Earth and have certainly put constraints on the formation of the earliest biopolymers. Therefore, they can be exploited in order to guess how the genome of the most primitive or-ganisms looked like. The information about the general characteristics of ancient life forms obtained using physical and chemical arguments may be used in the search of the remnants of the first genes which could be inside modern genes for instance due to processes of gene fu-sion. The lecture will end up with a discussion about the physical experimental methods that allow the detection of possible substructures inside biopolymers like proteins or DNA.

Extremophiles: Extreme environments are characterized by physical and chemical parameters which were considered lying outside the range which is suitable for life. In recent years, the notion of what constitutes life-limiting conditions in an environment has undergone dramatic changes: microorganisms and occasionally higher organisms were discovered, which not only tolerate, but thrive under ranges of temperatures, pH values, pressures, salinity, ionizing radia-tion etc. previously thought to destruct biomolecules and organisms. Some of the mechanisms responsible for these life styles are in the process of being elucidated. The presence of liquid water is a prerequisite for growth under all kinds of conditions; however, survival of resting stages, such as spores or dormant forms, was shown to occur in vacuum and in space condi-tions for several months. The detection of numerous viable prokaryotes and spores in subterra-nean locations, such as basalt, granite, ancient halite and sediments, suggests the possibility of extensive longevity, perhaps over millions of years.

The implications of these discoveries for the search for extraterrestrial life are severalfold: the probability of finding prokaryotic life in environments such as the subsurface of Mars or the salty ocean of the Jovian moon Europa appears greatly enhanced, and the potential for Panspermia is considered more plausible than ever before.

Questions
1. The search for extraterrestrial life is one of the scientific goals of the 21th century. But the term “life” is not clearly and unequivocally defined. What, in your opinion, should be search for?
2. Hypothesis: Mars is already contaminated with terrestrial microorganisms and there is no chance of detecting potential Martian forms of life. Would you agree or disagree?
3. Which molecular mechanisms enable microbial life at extreme temperatures?
